717800f-a.text:
Broadway and environs at Dyckman Street, as viewed northward from Fort George, Broadway is the thoroughfare just this side of Inwood Hill (knoll in the left center) and runs across the view from right to left: Dyckman Street being at the foot of same passing thru the gap formed, beyond which appear the Palisades of New Jersey as mounds in the far distance. To the right is the Metropolitan Railroad Co. power plant on the Harlem River at the foot of W. 216th Street, silhouetted against the Marble Hill outline of the Bronx Shore. This set consists of a photostatic positive and negative. For additional views at this date see Inwood Hill Park.

1904.
Brownn Bros.

719390f-a.text:
Graveyard of Mt. Washington Presbyterian Church, near the intersection of Dyckman Street and Riverside Drive.
1904.
Brown Brothers.
719390f-a.folder: Dyckman Street & Riverside Drive, Manhattan, NY

717807f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Dyckman to 204th Streets. Work is about to begin on the Eighth Avenue Subway.
April, 1926.

717806f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Dyckman to Cummings Streets, showing construction work on the Dyckman Street station of the Eighth Avenue subway.
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

At the intersection of Broadway and Riverside Drive, at Dyckman
Street.
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

but not including Payson Ave.
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

717803f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, at Dyckman Street, as viewed northeastward on Riverside Drive at Seaman Ave. Note the one story structures at both the S.E. and N.E. corners. The 6-story apartment house shown is No. 209 Dyckman Street, north side, east of Broadway.

September 14, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

717802f-b.text:
Broadway, at Dyckman Street. View 1 shows the G. F. Gantz house at the northwest corner of the intersection. View 2 shows an old house at Bennett avenue.

E. P. Chrystie               June 18, 1923
CREDIT LINE INITIATIVE       Views 1,2

1509033-a.title: Broadway #225 - Dyckman Street, looking southeast
1509033-a.folder: Broadway #225 - Dyckman Street, looking southeast, Manhattan, NY

722862f-a.text:
(1)
The intersection of Riverside Drive, (Boulevard Lafayette) and
Dyckman (Inwood) Street, at Broadway, (Kingsbridge Road). The view shows the Mount Washington Presbyterian Church (a frame structure), with the Parish House, adjoining. The Church was built in 1844-46, at "Tubby Hook", on the site of the old Black Horse Tavern of 1812.

October 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, a more inclusive view, showing the new Dyckman Arms Apts., adjoining on the drive side.

October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2, after the church and Parish House have been
demolished.

June 3, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

722862f-b.folder: Riverside Drive & Dyckman Street, Manhattan, NY

722863f-b.text:
(1 & 2)

Riverside Drive, at Dyckman Street, showing the new link connecting same with the Henry Hudson Parkway via a bridge over Dyckman Street and from which the photographer is viewing southward in No. 1. Formerly the Drive followed the contour of the stone wall and turned eastward to Broadway, skirting Fort Tryon Park in which the Cloisters, a branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is under construction. Southwest of same is the new George Washington Bridge across the North (Hudson) River at 181st Street. View No. 2 is northward from a point below the new Museum and across the Dyckman Street gap to Inwood Hill Park.

June 22, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
An earlier view of the same area. Note the original condition of Riverside Drive (cars thereon). The photographer states his vantage point to be near Dyckman Street and the Railroad.

June 3, 1934.
P. L. Speer.
